rev.diff:
Line 85: Line 85:
Haywood observed how the government frequently took the side of business to defeat the tactics and the aspirations of the miners.<Ref name=carlson-65>Carlson, 65.</Ref> During an 1899 organizing drive in [[Coeur d'Alene]], with pay cuts as a motivating issue, the company hired spies and then fired organizers and pro-union miners. Some frustrated miners responded with violence and when two men were killed, martial law was declared.<Ref name=carlson-54>Carlson, 54.</Ref> As they had done in a strike in Coeur d'Alene seven years earlier, soldiers acted as strike breakers. They rounded up hundreds of union members without formal charges and put them in a filthy, vermin-infested warehouse without sanitation services for a year. They were so crowded that the soldiers locked the overflow in boxcars.<Ref>Carlson, 55.</Ref> One local union leader was imprisoned for 17 years.<Ref name=carlson-54 />
Haywood observed how the government frequently took the side of business to defeat the tactics and the aspirations of the miners.<Ref name=carlson-65>Carlson, 65.</Ref> During an 1899 organizing drive in [[Coeur d'Alene]], with pay cuts as a motivating issue, the company hired spies and then fired organizers and pro-union miners. Some frustrated miners responded with violence and when two men were killed, martial law was declared.<Ref name=carlson-54>Carlson, 54.</Ref> As they had done in a strike in Coeur d'Alene seven years earlier, soldiers acted as strike breakers. They rounded up hundreds of union members without formal charges and put them in a filthy, vermin-infested warehouse without sanitation services for a year. They were so crowded that the soldiers locked the overflow in boxcars.<Ref>Carlson, 55.</Ref> One local union leader was imprisoned for 17 years.<Ref name=carlson-54 />
â
Haywood considered the brutal conditions in Coeur d'Alene a manifestation of class warfare. In 1901 the miners agreed at their convention that a "complete revolution of social and economic conditions" was "the only salvation of the working classes."<Ref>All That Glitters: Class, Conflict, and Community in Cripple Creek, Elizabeth Jameson, pp 179.</Ref>
+
Haywood considered the brutal conditions in Coeur d'Alene a manifestation of class warfare. In 1901 the miners agreed at their convention that a "complete revolution of social and economic conditions" was "the only salvation of the working classes."<Ref>Jameson, 179.</Ref>
In the WFM's 1903-05 struggle in Colorado, with martial law once again in force, two declarations uttered by the National Guard and recorded for posterity further clarified the relationship of the mine operator's enforcement army — provided courtesy of the Colorado governor — to the workers. When union attorneys asked the courts to free illegally imprisoned strikers, Adjutant General Sherman Bell declared, "[[Habeas corpus]] be damned, we'll give 'em [[Autopsy|post mortems]]."<Ref>Carlson, 62.</Ref> Reminded of the Constitution, one of Bell's junior officers declared coolly, "To hell with the Constitution. We're not going by the Constitution."<Ref>Carlson, 63.</Ref>
In the WFM's 1903-05 struggle in Colorado, with martial law once again in force, two declarations uttered by the National Guard and recorded for posterity further clarified the relationship of the mine operator's enforcement army — provided courtesy of the Colorado governor — to the workers. When union attorneys asked the courts to free illegally imprisoned strikers, Adjutant General Sherman Bell declared, "[[Habeas corpus]] be damned, we'll give 'em [[Autopsy|post mortems]]."<Ref>Carlson, 62.</Ref> Reminded of the Constitution, one of Bell's junior officers declared coolly, "To hell with the Constitution. We're not going by the Constitution."<Ref>Carlson, 63.</Ref>
[[Image:Bill_haywood_iww_convention.jpg|thumb|left|200|Haywood at a convention in Chicago (1917)]]
[[Image:Bill_haywood_iww_convention.jpg|thumb|left|200|Haywood at a convention in Chicago (1917)]]
â
General Bell had been the manager of one of the coal mines in Cripple Creek where the strike was taking place.<Ref>All That Glitters: Class, Conflict, and Community in Cripple Creek, Elizabeth Jameson, pp 140.</Ref> It wasn't any surprise to Haywood that soldiers seemed to be working in the interests of the employers, he'd seen that before.<Ref name=carlson-65 /> But when the Colorado legislature acknowledged the complaints of organized labor and passed an [[Eight-hour day|eight hour]] law, the Colorado supreme court declared it unconstitutional.<Ref>Carlson, 64.</Ref> So the WFM took the issue to the voters, and 72 percent of the state's voters approved the referendum.<Ref name=carlson-65 /> But the Cololorado government ignored the referendum.<Ref name=carlson-65 />
+
General Bell had been the manager of one of the coal mines in Cripple Creek where the strike was taking place.<Ref>Jameson, 140.</Ref> It wasn't any surprise to Haywood that soldiers seemed to be working in the interests of the employers, he'd seen that before.<Ref name=carlson-65 /> But when the Colorado legislature acknowledged the complaints of organized labor and passed an [[Eight-hour day|eight hour]] law, the Colorado supreme court declared it unconstitutional.<Ref>Carlson, 64.</Ref> So the WFM took the issue to the voters, and 72 percent of the state's voters approved the referendum.<Ref name=carlson-65 /> But the Cololorado government ignored the referendum.<Ref name=carlson-65 />
To the WFM, it became clear that government favored the companies, and only direct action by organized workers could secure the eight hour day for themselves. When miners in [[Idaho Springs]] and [[Telluride]] decided to strike for the eight hour day, they were rounded up by vigilante groups and expelled from their communities. Warrants were issued for the arrest of the vigilantes, but they were not acted upon.<Ref>Carlson, 64-65.</Ref>
To the WFM, it became clear that government favored the companies, and only direct action by organized workers could secure the eight hour day for themselves. When miners in [[Idaho Springs]] and [[Telluride]] decided to strike for the eight hour day, they were rounded up by vigilante groups and expelled from their communities. Warrants were issued for the arrest of the vigilantes, but they were not acted upon.<Ref>Carlson, 64-65.</Ref>
